body:
Hi!

This is the expected behavior. Since `firstException` is declared as a primitive boolean, it can't never be null. If the request does not include the parameter, Quarkus defaults it to `false`.

If you need to distinguish between “not provided” and an actual true/false value, you should declare the parameter as Boolean (the class). That way it can receive null when the parameter is missing.

Does it make sense?

Hi @aureamunoz 

Thank you for your reply, but I don't entirely agree with you.

Let me try to explain: If I have an endpoint that requires a request parameter, if that parameter is not passed, it is not correct to “land” at that endpoint anyway, as it would be correct to get a 404 NOT FOUND

However, with this implementation, even if I transform the parameter into a primitive, i.e. `Boolean` instead of `boolean`, if the parameter is not passed, the call still reaches the endpoint, which is not quite right

That's why I started the post, because it would be necessary to support `required=true` in the `@RequestParam` annotation so that we can identify whether it is correct or not that if the parameter is passed, we enter the endpoint or receive a 404...


Let me know if you understand what I mean
Ah, yes, you're right. And this is weird beacuse I remember having improved the support for implementing this behavior. I'll take a look.
@aureamunoz thank you, i will wait your response

issue.title: Modify @RequestParam presence handling

labels.name: area/spring
labels.description: Issues relating to the Spring integration

issue.body:
Fixes #50321

<!--
If this is your first time contributing to the project, 
please consider reviewing https://github.com/quarkusio/quarkus/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

Validate presence of parameters during the RESOLVE_METHOD_PARAMETERS and, if absent, throw exception to stop execution

<!--
Please include in the description above the list of GitHub issues this Pull Request addresses in the following format:

* Fixes #xxxxx
* Fixes #yyyyy
* Fixes #zzzzz
* ....

See https://docs.github.com/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issues/using-issues/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue
for more information about linking issues to the Pull Request.
-->

body:
Hi @GuidoFarport , I found it. Previously the validation was applied after the controller method was already invoked, meaning exceptions could be thrown inside the method before the missing parameter was detected. Now the check runs before method execution, so a proper 400 Bad Request is returned without entering the controller.

It has been fixed here: https://github.com/quarkusio/quarkus/pull/50400

> Hi [@aureamunoz](https://github.com/aureamunoz) Thank you for your reply, but will this trigger an exception that can be caught in the global exception handler? Is this `WebApplicationException` ?
> 
> As for the possibility of defining a `@RequestParam` (Spring annotation) as required or not required for an endpoint, is this feasible?

Hi @GuidoFarport 
Yes, the validation throws a WebApplicationException, which can be caught by your global exception handler.
In the reproducer it’s handled by `ExceptionMappersSpring#unsafedException`.

Regarding the required attribute of @RequestParam, it’s supported in Quarkus and works the same way as in Spring Web.
